description:
Actinemys pallida, also known as the pale western pond turtle, is a species of freshwater turtle native to the western United States. It belongs to the family Emydidae, which includes various pond and marsh turtles.

This species is characterized by its pale coloration, which can range from light gray to yellowish-tan on the carapace (upper shell) and plastron (lower shell). The head, neck, and limbs are also pale in color. Actinemys pallida has a relatively flat, oval-shaped carapace and can grow up to 8 inches (20 cm) in length.

The pale western pond turtle is found in slow-moving rivers, lakes, and ponds throughout the states of California, Oregon, Washington, and Nevada. It prefers areas with aquatic vegetation, basking sites, and nearby upland habitats for nesting and overwintering.

Like other pond turtles, Actinemys pallida is omnivorous, feeding on a variety of aquatic plants, insects, small fish, and carrion. It is an ectothermic (cold-blooded) species, relying on basking behavior to regulate its body temperature.

The pale western pond turtle is considered a species of conservation concern in some parts of its range due to habitat loss, pollution, and introduced predators. Ongoing efforts to protect and conserve this unique freshwater turtle are crucial for maintaining the species' ecological role and biodiversity in the western United States.
